items.title: YouTube is cracking down on gambling content. Here’s what’s changing
items.summary:
- YouTube announced a new policy banning links to "unapproved" gambling websites, effective March 19.
- Gambling content will be restricted for users under 18 and may take down videos promising guaranteed returns.
- Exceptions exist for content related to online sports betting and in-person gambling.
- This change is part of broader efforts to protect younger viewers, including improved age estimation technology.
- YouTube has previously banned gambling ads in specific placements and aims to address the surge of gambling content on its platform.

items.title: Deepfake scammers are hijacking TikTok’s wellness craze to sell dubious health products
items.summary:
- Deepfake technology is being used for scams on TikTok, where fake influencers promote dubious wellness products.
- A report from Media Matters identified multiple TikTok accounts using deepfake influencers and fake storytimes to sell these products with no scientific backing.
- One deleted account had over 245,000 followers and promoted a batana oil purported to enhance hair growth, featuring an AI-generated influencer.
- Scammers exploit popular TikTok formats like #storytime to market their products, often tying them to personal, relatable struggles.
- The report highlights a narrative designed to resonate with viewers, linking infertility and a questionable supplement to garner trust before selling a product.

items.title: Trump Signs Executive Order to Establish Bitcoin Reserve
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- President Donald Trump signed an executive order to create a government reserve of Bitcoin.
- The U.S. government will retain approximately 200,000 seized Bitcoins as a store of value, termed a digital Fort Knox.
- The executive order calls for a full accounting of Bitcoin holdings, with past sales valued at a potential loss of about $17 billion.
- Trump, once a Bitcoin skeptic, has adopted a pro-crypto stance, hosting a White House Crypto Summit and advocating for industry-friendly legislation.
- The order also establishes a "U.S. Digital Asset Stockpile" for other seized cryptocurrencies like XRP, Solana, and Cardano.

items.title: SpaceX’s Starship explodes again, with wreckage seen from Florida
items.author: Marcia Dunn
items.summary:
- SpaceX launched another Starship rocket but lost contact minutes into the flight, resulting in the spacecraft breaking apart over Florida.
- The rocket reached nearly 90 miles in altitude before its failure; wreckage was seen near Cape Canaveral.
- The incident leads to an investigation by the FAA, and flights at Orlando International Airport were temporarily grounded due to debris in the area.

items.title: Spotify’s leaning hard into video podcasts. Here’s how creators are adapting
items.summary:
- Spotify has opened a new revenue stream for podcasters who upload video content.
- Podcasting is shifting from audio-only to video formats, inspired by YouTube's success with one billion monthly podcast viewers.
- Spotify is rolling out new features and monetization tools, including a Partner Program for video podcasters that allows them to earn from premium subscriber streams.
- Jordan Newman, Spotify’s senior director of content partnerships, stated the company is encouraging video content to align with audience and creator trends.
- Fast Company interviewed various creators to understand their views on Spotify's video push, highlighting differing opinions between video adopters and audio-only podcasters.

items.title: Google’s ‘quiet’ decision to remove cultural events from its Calendar app sent a loud message
items.summary:
- Google Calendar will not display several cultural events, including South by Southwest (SXSW), Women’s History Month, and International Women’s Day.
- The removal aligns with a broader trend of companies distancing themselves from DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) terms.
- Users highlighted the absence of cultural observances like Black History Month, leading to scrutiny of Google's recent changes.

items.title: Creative Leaders Share How They're Harnessing AI in Work
items.author: Fast Company
items.summary:
- The article discusses an in-depth survey on how creative professionals use AI in their work.
- AI is now a routine part of the creative process for many, making a return to working without it nearly impossible.
- Respondents acknowledge AI as a powerful, though sometimes error-prone, collaborator in enhancing the creative process.
- A diverse cohort of creatives responded, with the majority being founders or in C-suite positions!
- Key industries represented include tech (22%), design (16%), and entertainment (14%).
- 83% of respondents integrate AI into their creative processes; 48% rely on it for most or all projects.

items.title: Glydways wants to reinvent transit—no more than four passengers at a time
Remembering how 18F modernized government technology
items.summary:
- Healthcare.gov launched in October 2013, facing technical issues with only 2,000 concurrent users.
- 18F was established on March 19, 2014, to modernize government digital services, derived from GSA's address, 1800 F Street.
- The Trump administration eliminated 18F on March 1, 2025, raising concerns about the future of government technology services.
- 18F improved public service technology, supporting projects like IRS Direct File, serving 30 million taxpayers in the 2025 season.

items.title: Why weird JD Vance memes have taken over the internet
items.summary:
- The meeting between Ukrainian President Zelenskyy and U.S. officials, including JD Vance, sparked a wave of memes surrounding Vance's reaction.
- Vance's boyish photo was altered to appear overly cherubic, leading to widespread mockery across social media platforms.
- The meme's evolution has included various cultural references, highlighting its bipartisan appeal among both critics and supporters of Vance.

items.title: How this sex-forward gay cruising site finally launched an Apple-approved iOS app
Gig Companies are backing Trump’s Labor Secretary nominee. Here’s what that means for workers
items.summary:
- America's largest gig companies are backing Trump's nominees for the Department of Labor, which could influence worker classification in the gig economy.
- Flex, a lobbying group with members like Uber, Lyft, and DoorDash, supports Lori Chavez-DeRemer and Keith Sonderling for key positions in the department.
- A change in labor classification from independent contractors to employees could significantly increase labor costs for gig companies, affecting their profitability and operational models.

items.title: TSMC’s $100 billion U.S. commitment could calm Taiwan tensions
items.summary:
- TSMC will invest $100 billion in U.S. operations over the next ten years.
- The investment will fund three new fabrication plants, R&D center, and advanced packaging facilities.
- TSMC has already committed $65 billion for chip facilities near Phoenix, Arizona.
- The U.S. government currently has no tariffs on imports from Taiwan but considers tariffs on Taiwanese semiconductors.
- TSMC's investment may help prevent the imposition of such tariffs by the Trump administration.
- TSMC plays a vital role in global semiconductor supply chains, heavily relying on U.S. customers like Nvidia.
- TSMC’s expansion abroad is driven by geopolitical tensions between the U.S. and China.

items.title: The Trump administration just cut Defense Department grants that research terrorism and drug trafficking
items.summary:
- Grants from the Department of Defense's Minerva Research Initiative are being terminated, risking research and employment for many involved.
- The Minerva program has funded crucial social science research on national security since 2008, addressing topics like Russian propaganda and U.S. military deployments.
- The recent funding cuts represent a shift in priorities under the Trump administration, despite the program's bipartisan support and relatively low annual cost.

items.title: Salesforce’s AI agents can decode tariffs in minutes
How Audiomack became an unlikely Spotify competitor
items.author: Brian Zisook, Dave Macli
items.summary:
- Audiomack is gaining popularity as a competitor to Spotify, especially in West Africa.
- The platform's current No. 1 album belongs to Nigerian artist Seyi Vibez, with 1.8 billion plays.
- Audiomack has 40 million monthly listeners, with half from Africa, demonstrating its strong local market presence.
- Founded in 2012 by Zisook and Macli to help local hip-hop DJs distribute mixtapes, Audiomack's growth surged in 2019 with West African users.
- The company hired a local team in Nigeria to better understand the market and avoid viewing Africa as a singular entity.

items.title: YouTube is doubling down on ‘bedtime’ reminders. Do they work?
items.summary:
- Teenage YouTube users globally will receive automatic reminders to go to bed and take breaks from screens.
- These reminders, first introduced in the U.S. seven years ago, are now toggled on by default for minors as of 2023.
- Effectiveness of the reminders is questionable, as users can easily dismiss them.
- YouTube's 'take a break' notification began in 2018, with over three billion warnings sent by 2020.
- Concerns about teen mental health have grown, prompting YouTube to make reminders more prominent in 2023.
- TikTok has also implemented similar features for screen time management for users under 18.

items.title: 'Dark woke' is the internet’s answer to Trump-style politics
items.summary:
- The term 'dark woke' emerged post-Trump's reelection, urging liberals to adopt a tougher, more aggressive approach.
- Examples include AOC's provocative comments and new strategies among Democrats like Robert Garcia.
- Critics argue that 'dark woke' often equates to using slurs under the guise of leftist language, reflecting a shift towards meaner politics influenced by Trump's style.

items.title: Utah just passed the country’s first age verification bill for app stores. But the fight isn’t over
items.summary:
- Utah has passed the App Store Accountability Act, mandating age verification for app store users and parental consent for minors.
- The bill is headed to Governor Spencer Cox's desk and reflects ongoing tensions between app stores and social media companies.
- Advocates argue the law will help protect children online, while critics believe it infringes on privacy and First Amendment rights.
- Significant push from parent groups contributed to the legislation's success, according to the sponsoring state representative Jim Dunnigan.
- The Digital Childhood Alliance sees this as part of a growing movement for accountability in the digital space.

items.title: This shaving brand was banned on TikTok, so it started an OnlyFans
items.summary:
- London-based razor brand [Nimbi](https://nimbi.supply/pages/our-ethos?contact_posted=true#ContactForm) faced low TikTok views due to a shadowban on the word "razor".
- Co-founder Anna Reid jokingly suggested using OnlyFans for marketing, leading to an unconventional approach.
- Nimbi posts instructional content on OnlyFans, providing educational techniques rather than sexualized content.
- Currently, Nimbi is the top seller in Erewhon's personal care category and will expand to more than 900 Target stores on March 1, 2024.
- Nimbi's razors are eco-friendly, made from waste wood pulp, pine oil, and clay, differentiating them from traditional plastic razors.

items.title: JetZero teams with Delta to take the first blended-wing body commercial jetliner closer to reality
items.author: Tom O’Leary, Mark Page, Amelia DeLuca
items.summary:
- JetZero partners with Delta to develop the first commercial blended-wing body (BWB) aircraft.
- CEO Tom O’Leary emphasizes the importance of efficiency in bringing the aircraft to market.
- The BWB design aims to achieve midbody jetliner speed and range using half the fuel, targeting a zero-carbon goal by 2050.
- Since its founding in 2021, JetZero has secured $300 million in investments and a $235 million award from the U.S. Air Force.
- Delta's Sustainable Skies Lab and TechOps will assist in refining aircraft economics and passenger experience.

items.title: Why these former rival founders are teaming up to revive Digg
items.author: Kevin Rose, Alexis Ohanian
items.summary:
- Digg founder Kevin Rose and Reddit cofounder Alexis Ohanian have partnered to revive the news aggregator Digg.
- They purchased Digg from its previous owners in early 2025 for an undisclosed sum, supported by True Ventures and Ohanian’s Seven Seven Six fund.
- Ohanian and Rose acknowledged their past rivalry, reflecting on their feelings of animosity towards each other during the early days of their respective platforms.

items.title: AI pioneers win the Turing Award, tech’s top prize
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Andrew Barto and Richard Sutton awarded the A.M. Turing Award for their work in reinforcement learning.
- Their research dates back to the late 1970s and has greatly influenced AI innovations over the past decade, such as beating human players in Go and enhancing ChatGPT.
- The annual prize, supported by Google, is currently worth $1 million and was announced by the Association for Computing Machinery.

items.title: Social media app Digg, a former Reddit rival, is relaunching
items.author: Kevin Rose, Alexis Ohanian, Justin Mezzell
items.summary:
- Digg, popular for up- and down-voting, is being relaunched by its founders, aiming for a focus on humanity and connection through AI.
- Originally launched in 2004, Digg peaked with 40 million monthly users before being sold in 2012.
- The new Digg will use AI for content moderation and is set to launch soon as both a website and mobile app.

items.title: Elon Musk’s court order against OpenAI gets blocked by federal judge
items.author: Matt O'Brien, Barbara Ortutay
items.summary:
- A federal judge denied Elon Musk's request for a court order to block OpenAI from becoming a for-profit company.
- Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers stated Musk did not show likelihood of success on the merits of his request.
- A trial may be expedited for Musk's claims against OpenAI and CEO Sam Altman this fall.
- Musk's lawsuit includes claims of breach of contract and unfair competition with his AI company, xAI.
- OpenAI welcomed the court's decision, emphasizing competition and Musk's past emails suggesting a merger with Tesla.
- The judge questioned Musk's claims of 'irreparable harm' and highlighted the lack of a written contract for his initial investment in OpenAI.

items.title: Tariffs will doom Trump’s attempt to pump crypto
items.summary:
- Trump has promised to facilitate Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies, aiming to reduce SEC regulation.
- He announced a “Crypto Strategic Reserve” to buy and hold cryptocurrencies with taxpayer money.
- Tariffs implemented on goods from China, Canada, and Mexico have negatively affected both traditional stock and crypto markets, with Bitcoin and Ethereum prices dropping.
- The connection between crypto and stock market movements suggests market volatility impacts both sectors similarly.

items.title: Facebook’s AI slop hellscape is already here
items.author: Harry McCracken
items.summary:
- A Meta executive has proposed that AI-generated profiles could operate on Facebook like real accounts, with bios and content sharing.
- Users are seeing a surge of AI-generated posts filled with bizarre imagery and narratives that provoke significant engagement.
- The authenticity of user interactions is questionable, as many comments seem to be directed toward these AI personas rather than real people.
- Users express concerns about the impact of AI-generated content on their feeds, often mistaking real posts for AI-generated ones.
- The author questions whether Meta should introduce AI members or focus on ensuring the presence of real individuals on the platform.

items.title: Does Donald Trump’s TSMC deal mean Taiwan just lost its Silicon Valley shield?
items.summary:
- President Trump announced a $100 billion deal with TSMC on March 3 to expand chip production in the U.S.
- The agreement includes plans for five new factories to be built in the United States, emphasizing national security.
- Concerns arise that this deal may strengthen U.S. security while weakening Taiwanese security and TSMC's market position.

items.title: Thousands of pedophiles are using jail-broken AI character chatbots to roleplay sexually assaulting minors
items.summary:
- In 2023, the NCMEC received over 36 million reports of suspected child sexual exploitation, indicating a 300% increase in online enticement cases.
- A report by Graphika reveals more than 10,000 chatbots being used for sexualized roleplay with minors, notably on platforms like 4chan.
- Many of these chatbots are jailbroken versions of AI models from OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google, despite no indication that these companies are aware of the abuse.
- About 100 chatbots are linked to popular AI services like ChatGPT and Claude, raising concerns about the safety of such platforms.
- The majority of offending chatbots were found on Chub AI, which hosts 7,140 chatbots labeled as sexualized minor characters, with claims that CSAM is not allowed on their platform.

items.title: This new dating app is bringing a Pokémon Go approach to romance
items.author: Samantha Martin, Kate Sieler
items.summary:
- A new dating app called [Left Field](https://left-field.co/) aims to combat swipe fatigue.
- It uses location-based notifications for real-life meet-cutes instead of traditional swiping.
- Founded by Samantha Martin and Kate Sieler in response to frustrations with existing dating apps, they gathered feedback from over a hundred Gen Zers.
- The app launched on the Apple App Store in February and plans to expand to college campuses in May.
- Left Field is hosting in-person events and collaborating with influencers to build its community.

items.title: This DOGE staffer’s GitHub posts might help us understand how Elon Musk wants to bring AI into the government
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Jordan Wick, a staffer at the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), shared GitHub posts that provide insight into potential AI applications in government operations.
- Among the tools he posted is one for downloading direct messages from Twitter accounts, which might be used to review government employees' past opinions.
- Another tool collects sensitive data from federal agencies, raising concerns about creating an AI model for employee evaluations and firings, aligning with DOGE’s goals of efficiency.
- Wick's background includes experience at Waymo and co-founding Accelerate SF, which aims to leverage AI for improving government services.

items.title: Casey Anthony joins TikTok and Substack to ‘advocate’ for herself
items.summary:
- Casey Anthony reemerges on TikTok more than a decade after being accused of her daughter's murder.
- In her first video, she identifies herself as a legal advocate and researcher, emphasizing the need to advocate for herself and her daughter Caylee.
- Anthony's daughter went missing in 2008; her body was found later that year, and Anthony was acquitted of murder in 2011 but convicted of lying to police.
- The TikTok video has over 3.3 million views, although comments are disabled.
- Anthony announces the launch of a Substack newsletter to provide resources and support for legal matters, while advocating for various communities including LGBTQ and women's rights.

items.title: Elon Musk’s bumbling X posts are inadvertently teaching everyone how government works
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's posts on X reveal his lack of understanding of civics and data science, sparking explanations from experts.
- Discussions around air traffic control staffing and flight trajectories highlight misconceptions Musk has shared.
- The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by health care entrepreneur Brad Smith, was supposed to inform Musk about government processes, but he prefers a rapid, reckless approach.
- Musk publicly denied that cost-cutting at DOGE affected cancer research funding, but experts clarified the importance of related overhead costs in biomedical research support.

items.title: Mozilla’s new message: We’re the only browser not backed by billionaires
items.author: Laura Chambers
items.summary:
- Mozilla Firefox is highlighted as being independent and nonprofit, unlike other major browsers.
- CEO Laura Chambers states that Mozilla is the only browser not backed by billionaires.
- New features aimed at improving user navigation are set to launch in March, including a vertical tab display and a sidebar for switching between AI chatbots.
- Additional support for tab groups is expected later in spring or summer, a feature long requested by users.

items.title: Used Tesla prices depreciated more than any other automaker in 2024
items.summary:
- The average price of used Tesla's Model Y depreciated by 25.5% from January 2024 to January 2025.
- The average price of used Model 3 dropped by 25% in the same timeframe.
- In comparison, Nissan Maxima's price dropped by only 5.2% and Ford Mustang by 5%.
- The analysis focused on used cars from model years 2015 through 2023, excluding Model S and Model X.
- Factors affecting Tesla's depreciation include significant price cuts made to boost demand and changes aligning its products with consumer technology depreciation timelines.

items.title: Uber will now pair Austin riders with Waymo self-driving cars
items.summary:
- Uber has launched a service in Austin to match riders with Waymo self-driving cars.
- This partnership expands from Waymo's existing service in Phoenix, with plans for Atlanta next.
- Riders can match with a Waymo Jaguar I-PACE vehicle at no extra cost when requesting certain types of Uber rides.
- Customers will receive notifications for autonomous vehicle matches and can choose to accept or switch to a non-autonomous ride.
- The launch coincides with the upcoming SXSW festival, expected to attract many visitors.

items.title: TikTok’s ‘airport theory’ dares you to arrive just 15 minutes before your flight
items.summary:
- A viral TikTok trend called 'airport theory' suggests arriving just 15 minutes before a flight.
- The theory has garnered over 400 million views on TikTok.
- Travelers report mixed results with some successfully boarding flights while others miss them entirely.
- Examples include Lexi Smith, who made her flight after clearing security in 5 minutes, and Michael DiCostanzo, who cleared security in just over 7 minutes at Atlanta International Airport.
- However, users like Jenny Kurtz warn against the theory, explaining she missed her flight after trying it.

items.title: The third coming of Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman
items.author: Harry McCracken
items.summary:
- Microsoft employees demonstrate a strong focus and urgency as they navigate their workplace on a cold February morning.
- The article discusses the evolving role of Mustafa Suleyman within Microsoft AI and the company's future direction.
- Insight into Microsoft's corporate culture and initiative towards innovation and success is provided through on-site observations.

items.title: Popular female streamers are bringing on security after stars were attacked during an IRL stream
items.summary:
- Female streamers are advised to hire security following recent attacks during streams.
- On March 2, streamers Valkyrae, Cinna, and Emiru faced a threatening incident at Santa Monica Pier, which resulted in ending their live broadcast.
- Cinna updated fans via X, reassuring them of their safety and the need for time to process the event.
- Other streamers, like xChocoBars, highlight the need for more protective measures for women in streaming.
- QTCinderella shared her experience of hiring security for public streaming and its importance for safety.
- Amouranth reported being robbed at gunpoint for her crypto funds later that night, recounting the terrifying experience on social media.

items.title: Hulu ended its first live Oscars stream before the final awards. Viewers weren’t happy
items.summary:
- Hulu's livestream cut off during the final moments of the Oscars, missing key awards for best actress and best picture.
- Viewers saw an error message instead of the concluding segments, leading to widespread anger online.
- Some users experienced issues logging in at the start, causing them to miss the musical intro.
- Disney, which operates Hulu, apologized for the technical issues affecting viewers.

items.title: MrBeast lost ‘tens of millions’ on his Amazon show. That’s a sign for other creators
items.author: Jimmy Donaldson
items.summary:
- MrBeast, real name Jimmy Donaldson, reported losses of ‘tens of millions’ from Amazon’s *Beast Games*.
- The production costs were hundreds of millions, largely out-of-pocket by MrBeast.
- The show achieved 50 million viewers in 25 days, Amazon's second-largest series debut in 2024.
- Despite viewership success, critical reception was poor, and MrBeast did not gain significant new fans.
- Legal issues arose due to lawsuits from contestants for harassment and mistreatment.
- MrBeast's YouTube follower growth remained modest during the show's release.

items.title: Trump’s crypto reserve is a payoff for loyalists
items.summary:
- Trump announced a 'Crypto Strategic Reserve' via Truth Social, including Bitcoin, Ethereum, and three other cryptocurrencies.
- The announcement drove up the prices of several cryptocurrencies, notably Solana (up 20%), XRP (25%), and Cardano (56%).
- There are concerns about the rationale and implications of the reserve, which may primarily benefit Trump's supporters and crypto lobbyists rather than the government.

items.title: EV-maker BYD seeks to raise $5.2 billion with share sale
items.summary:
- BYD has launched a Hong Kong share sale to raise up to $5.2 billion.
- The price range for the shares is set at HK$333-HK$345, reflecting an 8.4% discount to the HK$363.60 closing price.
- Proceeds will be used for research and development, expanding overseas businesses, and general purposes.

items.title: AI Chatbots have telltale quirks. Researchers can spot them with 97% accuracy
items.author: Mingjie Sun, Yida Yin
items.summary:
- Researchers at four U.S. universities have identified linguistic fingerprints of large language models (LLMs).
- A machine learning model distinguished outputs from five popular LLMs with 97.1% accuracy.
- Unique verbal quirks were found for each model, revealing specific usage patterns in their responses.

items.title: More Americans watch YouTube on TV than on their smartphones—here’s what that means for creators and viewers
items.summary:
- YouTube celebrated its 20th birthday; users watch over a billion hours of content daily.
- TV viewership of YouTube has surpassed smartphone viewership in the U.S. for the first time.
- The shift back to TV is attributed to better TV technology, lower costs, and more people cutting the cord.
- Creators are adapting content for TV by investing in higher video quality and longer formats, with 4K uploads increasing by 35% year over year.

items.title: How and when to use voice AI like Letterly and Oasis
items.summary:
- Voice AI tools can help transform spoken thoughts into organized text more effectively than traditional transcription.
- Benefits of voice AI include instant transformation into drafts, smart cleanup of filler words, format flexibility, and context awareness.
- Suggested uses for voice AI are for journal entries and capturing meeting follow-ups, allowing for more natural and efficient note-taking.

items.title: Everything you need to know about the Oscars’ AI controversy
items.summary:
- Best Actress nominee Mikey Madison and Timothée Chalamet trained for roles but AI was used for voice enhancement in Oscar-nominated films.  
- Controversial use of AI in films like *The Brutalist* and *Emilia Pérez* has sparked backlash over authenticity and job security concerns.  
- The Motion Picture Academy may require filmmakers to disclose AI use in films amidst ongoing debates about AI's role in the industry.

items.title: Curious about DeepSeek but worried about privacy? These apps let you use an LLM without the internet
items.summary:
- Internet chatbots like [ChatGPT](https://www.fastcompany.com/91269024/openai-china-deepseek-fair-use-copyright-fight) and [DeepSeek](https://www.fastcompany.com/91267354/deepseek-explained-china-llm-chatgpt-nvidia-microsoft-stock-ai-rattled) require an internet connection and send user inputs to company servers, raising privacy concerns.
- Desktop applications like [LM Studio](https://lmstudio.ai/) and [GPT4All](https://www.nomic.ai/gpt4all) allow users to run LLM models locally, bypassing these privacy issues.
- These apps are free to use and support multiple open-source LLMs, providing a user-friendly interface similar to online chatbots.

items.title: Tired of overdramatic TikTok food influencers? Professional critics are too
items.summary:
- TikTok and Instagram are flooded with food influencers boosting restaurants, often through exaggerated reviews.
- The U.K.'s Guild of Food Writers criticized influencers, urging more honest reviews.
- Chetna Makan from the Guild expressed distrust in online food videos due to difficulty in distinguishing genuine reviews from promotional content.
- Influencers like Keith Lee gain large followings despite lacking formal culinary qualifications, leading to a shift in who people trust for food reviews.
- Many influencers are invited for free meals and engage in lucrative brand partnerships, raising questions about the integrity of their content.

items.title: Intel’s anticipated $28 billion chip factories in Ohio are delayed until 2030
items.summary:
- Intel's $28 billion chip factories in Ohio are delayed until 2030.
- First factory in New Albany expected to start operations in 2030 or 2031.
- Intel originally planned to begin chipmaking in 2025, but has since adjusted timelines to align with market demand.
